description:
Podospora comata is a species of ascomycete fungus that belongs to the family Lasiosphaeriaceae. It is commonly known as the "hairy Podospora" due to the distinct tufts of hair-like structures (setae) that cover the surface of its fruiting bodies (perithecia).

Podospora comata is a coprophilous fungus, meaning it grows on dung and other decaying organic matter. Its perithecia are small, typically ranging from 0.5 to 1 millimeter in diameter, and are dark-colored, often with a blackish or brownish hue. The setae that cover the perithecia are long, septate, and dark-colored, giving the fungus a distinctive, hairy appearance.

The asci (spore-bearing structures) of Podospora comata are cylindrical and contain eight ascospores. The ascospores are elliptical to fusiform in shape and are typically dark-colored, with or without a distinct germ pore.

Podospora comata is commonly found in temperate and tropical regions, where it plays a role in the decomposition of animal dung and other organic matter. It is of interest to mycologists and microbiologists due to its unique morphological features and ecological significance in nutrient cycling within various ecosystems.
